Award.AwardTitle: Midwest Apex Project (MAP): Road MAP for Student Excellence in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Over the five-year grant period, the Midwest Apex Project (MAP) is awarding 84 MAP scholarships, averaging $5,600 per year, and 81 MAP incentive awards of $600 per award. The program targets baccalaureate majors in biology, chemistry, computer science, engineering technology and mathematics at Missouri Western State University (MWSU). By providing extensive student support to awardees, including cohort building through and online virtual community and through common course work, learning communities, peer study groups, study sessions, a brown bag lunch series, an annual orientation program, and intensive mentoring, MAP is achieving the following programmatic objectives: 1) improved accessibility to MWSU education resources, 2) increased financial support, 3) enhanced retention through graduation, and 4) increased placement of students in applied learning opportunities with regional employers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Description

The Midwest Apex Project (MAP):  Road Map for Student Excellence in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics was a five-year project designed to support students majoring in STEM fields at Missouri Western State University.  Awards were provided at two levels including one time incentive awards of $600 and renewable scholarships that averaged $4,400 per year.  Students accepted into the program (at either level of scholarship funding) were provided with extensive support including cohort building, peer student groups, study sessions led by faculty or peer leaders, a brown bag lunch series, access to over 20 STEM related seminars per year, an annual orientation program, and intensive mentoring.  The programmatic objectives were to:

 

  • Improve accessibility to education resources at Missouri Western State University.
  •  Provide increased financial support to students in STEM fields.
  •  Improve persistence to graduation relative to University averages.
  •  Increase applied learning opportunities for program students.

 

 About Missouri Western State University (MWSU)

Located in St. Joseph, MO MWSU is one of two open admission institutions in the state of Missouri.   MWSU has an appointed statewide mission in applied learning. Currently MWSU has approximately 6000 undergraduate students and 120 graduate students. Located in St. Joseph, Missouri, 75% of MWSU students come from a 10 county region around St. Joseph, MO.

 As an open admissions institution MWSU is unique in the State of Missouri including:

 

  • A significant fraction of incoming students are academically unprepared for college with the average incoming ACT composite of 21.3.
  • Students qualify for need-based aid at a level that is nearly 17% greater than the average at Missouri four-year public higher education institutions. Additionally, MWSU students have one of the lowest average income levels in the Missouri four-year public sector. 61% received need based aid in 2014, while 83.5% of students receive some form of financial aid.
  • 48% of the incoming freshman class are first generation college students.
  • 80% of MWSU students work more than 20 hours a week.
  • The average incoming ACT composite score was 21.3 in 2014.

 

 Selection Criteria

Freshman applicants were required to have an ACT composite ≥ 23; and returning student applicants were required to have a GPA ≥ 3.0 and have completed college algebra, trigonometry or pre-calculus with a grade of B or better. All applicants were required to enroll in a STEM course required for their major in their first term.  In addition to demonstrating financial need, applicants were required to submit:  1)  A description of their professional goals and interests; 2)  A letter of recommendation from a former teacher or college faculty member.  Awardees were required to be full time students and US citizens or permanent residents.

 Mentoring Activities

All scholarship recipients were assigned a faculty mentor in their field of interest.  Students met with their faculty mentor on a monthly basis during the academic year during which they discussed academic progress, and short and long term goals for both their academic and career aspirations.
